If Black were to play Nxe4 in the following position, because the pawn at e4 is attacked three times, and only supported twice, it would be an obvious miscalculation, for the value of the defending pieces is smaller.
The only pieces available on the first move are the Knights.
In order to develop other pieces as well, it is necessary to move pawns first, and such pawn moves will be best as give an outlet to as many pieces as possible.

Generally speaking it is only required to move two or three pawns to allow all pieces to be developed, and it is good, on principle, to make only such pawn moves in the opening, which are necessary for the development of pieces.
To play other pawns really means the loss of a move.

In the second main line of defence, of which I shall treat now, Black renounces the maintenance of his e Pawn, and makes an attempt to find compensation by attacking White's King's Pawn.
The King's file, opened by the disappearance of the Black pawn, offers opportunities for that purpose.
The exchange on the seventh move is compulsory, because the loss of a pawn after Bxc6 is in effect threatened, now that the White e Pawn is supported by the Rook.
Black's intention of exerting pressure on the e Pawn is now difficult of execution, because his pieces are very cramped and hinder one another in a restricted area.
The Bishop in particular cannot be brought into action without great difficulty, for instance by: Re8 Bf8 g6 and Bg7.
It is therefore advisable for White to develop his Bishop at b2 instead of at g5 in order not to give Black a chance of exchanging his troublesome Bishop.
(In a game Bernstein-Emanuel Lasker, Moscow, 1914, there happened 9. Bxc6 bxc6 10. Bg5 h6 11. Bh4 Nh7 12. Bxe7 Qxe7 with a good game for Black.)
The defence has a totally different trend, if Black gives up his own e Pawn, but captures the White e Pawn at once.

Yet he can retaliate, not by making the simplest and most obvious developing moves, as mentioned before, but in the following way: If White plays 5. b3 before castling, Black exchanges pawns and checks with the Queen.
The former must be bad, being contrary to the plan of development as intended by b3.
The latter blocks the very diagonal on which the Bishop was meant to operate.
But in any case there remains the disadvantage that White was forced to play the c Pawn, whilst before he had the option of withholding its advance until a more opportune moment.
Another possible subtlety in Black's sequence of developing moves would be to withhold the advance of his e Pawn until White has played b3, and then to play the Bishop to g5.
For, as I have already remarked, the objection to developing Black's Queen's Bishop lies in White's threat to attack Black's b Pawn with Qb3.
That possibility disappears after b3.

Before bringing the discussion of the Queen's Pawn opening to a close, I may remark that in tournaments it has become usual for White not to play c4 at once, but to play Nf3 as a preliminary, in order to avoid the complications of the Queen's counter gambit:

In practice it has been shown that the end-game should be won by White in spite of Bishops of opposite colours, as Black's pawn at his c5 is difficult to defend.
The game is much more favourable for Black if he first plays 3. ... a6 and retains the option of driving the White B away by b5 after which d5 can be enforced very soon.

On the other hand, it cannot be denied that Black's B formation on the d side is weak, and that his centre is less secure.
Whilst White has a pawn firmly posted in the centre, Black has a pawn there which will soon be driven away.

Therefore Black must not delay playing 6. ... b5. After 7. It is therefore necessary to play c3 first.
The pawn at c6 supports an advance in the centre, and also provides a retreat for the Bishop.
The Knight can be developed in this way: Nd7, Nc8, Nb6 or Ne6.
Black's pawns at e5 and c5 then exert a pressure on White's d5.
And this pressure threatens to be reinforced by Bb4.
An attempt to free the King's file through e5 is conceivable.
But White can prevent this by simply playing Nf6.

Two other possibilities present themselves: after playing e6, Nf6 and Nd7, Black could steer into a line similar to the Queen's gambit accepted with dxc4 and c5, or he could keep the centre closed with f5 and Nf6, with the intention of playing Ne4 and using the f file for activating his Rook via f6.

Already on the second move White can play 2. c4 and turn the game into a Queen's gambit, which Black can either accept or decline.
But Black is well advised to wait until White has moved the King's Bishop before taking the pawn on his c5.
It would be quite incorrect to try to hold the pawn by b5 as follows: 2. c4 dxc4 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 b5 5. a4
If now Black answers bxa4 White simply plays Bxc4 and the P at a4 is lost very soon.
These considerations point to the conclusion that after 2. c4 there is no inducement for Black to take the pawn.

The attempt to develop the Queen's Bishop before playing e3 is not to be recommended, because the Knight's pawn remains unprotected and open to an immediate attack by 3. Qb3. Of the two remaining replies, 2. ... e6 and 2. ... c6 I will first discuss the former, as being the more natural of the two, since c3 does not fit into the scheme for opening the c file for the pawns.
According to the principles set out above, Nc6 would have been better, since the text move shuts out the King's Bishop.
Black would thus forfeit his chance of castling and lose much time in bringing the King into safety and the Rooks into play.
Protecting the pawn with the Queen would also block other pieces, and Nd7 cannot be good, as it blocks the Queen's Bishop.
This manoeuvre is, however, ill-advised, as Black is forced to exchange the Bishop for the Knight.
The Bishop will have moved twice, the Knight only once, therefore White will have gained a move for his development.

The text move, which is forced, blocks the Bishop, and at the same time prevents the development of the King's Rook, all of which is the direct consequence of the loss of one move.

A. We have already come to the conclusion that after 1. e4 e5 White does well to try to force the exchange of Black's centre pawn on d4 or f4 and that Black will try to counteract this, unless by allowing the exchange he gets a chance of exerting pressure in the centre by means of his pieces.
Superficially the difference between 2. d4 and 2. f5 is that in the first case the pawn thus advanced is covered, while in the second it is not.
An opening in which a pawn sacrifice is offered, is called a "gambit"; 2. f4 is therefore a gambit.
2. d4 is only a gambit if after 2. ... dxe5 White does not recapture the pawn.
For: 2. d4 threatens to take the King's Pawn.
To defend it by means of 2. ... c6 is unwise, since White exchanges pawns and then Queens, by which Black loses his chance of castling and impedes the development of his Rooks.
2. ... Nc6 is also bad, since after 3. dxe5 Nxe5 4. f4 White drives the Knight away, gaining a strong hold on the centre, and Black has no compensation for giving up his centre pawn.
We conclude now that Black cannot hold his pawn at e5.

He must relinquish the centre by 2. ... exd4. He will now either attempt to bring away White's King's Pawn by advancing his own d Pawn to d5 or try to utilise the e file, which was opened by his second move, and operate against White's e Pawn.
The Rooks are indicated for this task.
In the King's gambit, White's attempt to bring away Black's King's Pawn may be safely ignored.
The move 2. f4 does not threaten to take the King's Pawn, as Black would win White's e Pawn by Qh4+.

Black can therefore develop in security with 2. ... Bc5 and if then White prevents the Q check by Nf3 there is no objection to Black protecting his King's Pawn with d6 as the King's Bishop is already developed.
After 4. Bc4 Black has still no need to protect his e Pawn with Nc6 but can play Nf6 first, because after 5. fxe5 dxe5 6. Nxe5 would be answered by 6. ... Qd4 winning a piece.
Diagram 18 shows the position which results from the following plausible moves: 2. f4 Bc5 3. Nf3 d6 4. Bc4 Nf6 5. d3 Nc6 6. Nc3 Bg4
If White wishes to castle on the K side, which must have been his intention when playing 2. f4 he will have to play Na4 and Nxc5.

If then White plays f5 in order to hinder the development of Black's Bishop and to bring out his own, the pressure on Black's e Pawn is relieved permanently, and sooner or later Black will break through on the d file, as his d Pawn is no longer needed at d6 for the support of the centre pawn.
A different pawn formation is the result if White enforces the exchange of Black's centre pawn at once.

It is therefore unwise for the beginner to accept the gambit, unless there be a chance of compensation for the disappearance of his centre pawn, by forcing the exchange of White's centre pawn as well.

On principle it does not seem advisable for Black to play d5 on the first move in reply to 1. e4. Although White's centre pawn disappears after 2. exd5 Qxd5 Black loses a move through 3. Nc6 and his Queen has no place from which it cannot be driven away very soon, unless it be at d8.
There are two moves which deserve consideration as a preliminary to d4 namely, 1. ... e6 (French Defence) and c6 (Caro-Kann defence).
For after 4. ... dxc3 5. Nxc3 (Diagram 20) White has developed both Knights, and his Bishops are free, whilst Black has none of his pieces out.
[Footnote: A pawn is said to be "backward," when it cannot move into cover by another pawn.] at d6 is open to constant attacks and is difficult to defend.
Black is able to play d5 early in all such openings, where White does not force the defensive move d3 by attacking Black's King's Pawn.

After 3. exd5 e4 (to permit of Nf3, which at present is not feasible on account of 4. exd3) 4. d3 exd3 5. Qxd3 White is a pawn ahead, but his Queen obstructs his Bishop therefore Black has better developing chances and should be able to win the pawn back at the very least.
A second example is the Vienna game, which proceeds as follows: 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. f4 d5 (Diagram 21)
If White plays 4. exd5 Black can play e5 as in the Falkbeer gambit mentioned just now.
In answer to 4. fxe5 on the other hand, Black can play Nxe4 without having the slightest difficulty with his development.
For instance, 5. Nf3 Be7 6. d4 f6 7. Bd3 Nxc3 8. bxc3 O-O 9. O-O Nc6 or Bg4 and Black also will soon have an open file for his Rook, with no disadvantage in position.
The initial moves are: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5.
At first, therefore, Black need not provide against the threatened exchange.
Black can only maintain his centre pawn if he can prevent his Knight from being exchanged.
These considerations lead to the first main line of defence in which Black plays 3. ... a6. After 4. Ba4 Black has the option of releasing the pin by playing b5 at some opportune moment.

After 2. d4 exd4 White has the option of sacrificing two pawns to obtain a very rapid development 3. c3 dxc3 4. Bc4 cxb2 5. Bxb2. It may now be just possible for Black to avoid the many threats which White can bring to bear with his beautifully placed forces, perhaps by giving back one or both of the pawns gained.
After 4. exd5 Qxd5 Black's position is at least as easy of development as White's.
The equalising power of Black's d5 in all e Pawn openings where White has played d4 can be noticed in many variations.
In no case should Black forfeit his chance of playing d5.

It is tempting after 2. d4 exd4 3. Nf3 to cover the pawn at d5 by c4, but in that case White would sacrifice a pawn by c3, by this means opening the Queen's file for himself, and so preventing Black from ever playing d5.
Thus, for the loss of a pawn, White has a paramount advantage in position.
On the other hand, it cannot be denied that Black's pawn formation on the d side is weak, and that his centre is less secure.
Whilst White has a pawn firmly posted in the centre, Black has a Knight there which will soon be driven away.
White's d4 the basis of his centre, is entirely in his hands, whilst Black's d5 is exposed to a steady pressure by the White pieces.
Finally Black's Knight is unfavourably placed, obstructing as it does the c Pawn and preventing its falling into line with its fellows.

The openings as sketched out up to this point give a sufficiently clear idea of the possibilities of combining sound development with an attempt to capture the centre after the opening moves 1. e4 e5.
In most cases, Black's centre pawn being open to attack by White's d4 we find an early break-up of the centre, and concurrently the opening of the e or d files for the Rooks.

We attain typical close positions when Black does not play 1. ... e5 in answer to 1. e4 but relinquishes all claim on his e5 and takes possession of his d5 instead, leaving White the option of interlocking the pawns in the centre with e5.

Is he to play e5 and prevent the opening of the d or e file for a long time to come, or should he proceed to develop his pieces, and leave Black the option of anticipating the blocking of the centre by playing dxe4 himself?
The position which ensues in the centre after 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. e5 divides the board diagonally, and it is easy to recognise roughly the main lines of play which will govern the game.
White has more scope on the King's side, where his pieces will have greater mobility, and prospects of attack.
Black's chances are on the Queen's side.

Both sides will have to advance more pawns in order to obtain openings for their Rooks, and use them for the attack, since they have no future on the e and d files, as was the case in the openings mentioned hitherto.
This means for both sides e4 and d4, and also in a lesser degree c4 and f4.

In most cases two centre squares become inaccessible at once, through the opponent placing one of his pawns in the centre; therefore it would seem a good plan to lure that pawn away, and this is rendered feasible by playing e4 or c4 when the opponent has a pawn on his d4, and d4 or f4 when he has a pawn on e4.
Naturally, should White lose a move, as, for instance, 1. e4, e5 2. Nf3, Nc6; 3. a3? the position is reversed, and Black is bound to obtain the initiative which is White's birthright.
A Rook standing behind an advanced pawn may support its further advance, or, if the pawn should be exchanged, might get an open file.
Thus we will not easily give up a centre pawn unless we can obtain some other advantage in doing so.
Black might be justified in taking the pawn, if he really could hold the pawn thus gained.
We shall show later on that this is not so, and that White can win it back easily and advantageously.
For after exchanging his Bishop for the Knight, which otherwise would drive his Queen away, Black brings the latter into a dominating square in the centre.

When the pawns concerned are on the opposite wing to their King, the disadvantages of a premature advance are felt in a different way.
The weakness concerns the pawns themselves and not the forces behind them, and is apt to cause the loss of the end-game, particularly of Rook end-games.
In the one case the chain of Black pawns is broken by the absence of g Pawn, in the other of the b Pawn.

Here the pawn positions on both sides are broken, and the player that occupies the open files first, gets a decisive advantage.
